Reviews.Title: “Outdated”
Reviews.Author: Dakini68
Reviews.Content: I found this hotel to be very large, impersonal and expensive.  I know this hotel was built by a famous Mexican architect but I found it to be straight out of the 70s and totally outdated.    The hallways were full of loud people at late hours of the night.  The courtesy breakfast was lame and the restaurant had zero ambience.  On a positive note, the room was large, clean, the bed was comfy and the inner garden was nice and quiet.  It is also well-situated in Polanco. I would not return here again though.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: gferraez
Reviews.Content: The hotel is perfectly located in pPolanco at a very centric spot of the city, the only complain I have its that it is a little old Oder than that is Exelent

Reviews.Title: “Rooms falling apart/ customer service nonexistent”
Reviews.Author: RobertBlau
Reviews.Content: First time I stay at this hotel, booked through their website and chosen because of location and reasonable rates. Absolutely the worst mistake we could have made. Although check-in was quick, both of our rooms had huge problems due to the run-down state of the accomodations; sure enough, the lobby and public areas are reasonably kept so one has no idea what horror awaits at the rooms. Our shower had either no cold water (first 2 days of our stay), clogged drains (all of our stay), or no hot water (any time between midnight and 5am). Some windows in the rooms have newspapers stuck around the frames instead or sealing gaskets or insulation, resulting in noise all the time. Housekeeping staff congregated outside our rooms to chat in the early mornings, waking us up every time. Lamps in the rooms were broken or hanging from the walls, TV cable service and remote controls dated and non-functioning, and to top it off absolutely no way to get through to top management so they can fix the issues or at least apologize. We were moved to a different "better" room on our last night but by then the damage to our holiday had been done. This is the last time we stay at this hotel or any Camino Real in Mexico; since it is a local Mexican chain and the hotels are not franchised, apparently there is no pressure to update or maintain the buildings properly as with supervised franchisees all over the world. I strongly recommend not to stay in this hotel if you want to enjoy your stay in Mexico City and do not have the time or patience to keep arguing with uninterested staff.

Reviews.Title: “Knockout architecture, a little faded at the edges”
Reviews.Author: RexDS
Reviews.Content: On my first visit to Mexico City in 1998, the Camino Real was beyond the expense accounts of mere international bureaucrats, but I have fond memories of a dinner there, comprising Mexican specialties and the world’s best Margharita. In fact two of the latter, which may have been one more than optimal. Thus, I was pleased to be booked in there for my latest trip: it turns out that while not exactly cheap, the Camino is no longer (it appears) quite in the top rank of Mexican hotels price-wise. Rooms start at around US$130 plus 18.5% taxes on the weekends. The Camino’s key draw is it’s architecture: opened in 1968, it was designed by one of Mexico’s most prominent architects and features a sort of earthy take on modernism with clear indigenous elements. As design, it has stood up well. The semi-enclosed courtyard entry with its round “wave pool” fountain at centre, its pink latticed screen dividing it from the street and the supersized, stone-framed chairs alongside the driveway provides an arresting entrance. These are followed by an entry through an ancient pair of church doors to a sculpture-laden lobby from which open bars, the reception area and a broad stairway to the upstairs restaurants and bars. There are several of the latter, serving a range of cuisines and, on limited acquaintance, they reach a pretty good standard: Excellent guacamole and traditional duck mole on the first night and, more surprisingly perhaps, an ability to produce European standards properly - a fine eye fillet in green peppercorn sauce, cooked rare as ordered and accompanied by a very good Faustino Reserva Rioja. The rooms themselves are arranged around a pretty internal garden, with a pool and terrace at one end. Tip: spend an extra $25 a night for a garden view room, which will give you the aforesaid view and be a lot quieter - the hotel is located on a main street. Those on the ground floor open to the garden – but this means that you may not want to leave your sliding door open to the cool night air. This is a problem, because the airconditioning system seems to be a case of much sound and fury, signifying nothing. In fact, I moved rooms after the second night as, not only did my aircon seem to be impervious to human commands, half of the (barely adequate) lighting in my room was non-functional. Unfortunately, while the lights in the new room initially all worked (one blew a couple of days later, as had one in the first room) the aircon situation was unimproved. This brings me to the key point about the Camino: as the price drop suggests, it is in the latter phase of the cycle through which major hotels pass between renovations. It’s a little hard to tell how long it has been since the last, but the pink slate bathrooms show evidence of neglect, in that the slate in the showers hasn’t been resealed and has taken on milky white staining as a consequence, giving them a grimy appearance. The tapware is worn, with flaking chrome and just about functioning sink plugs, and so on. The rooms lack modern conveniences such as IPod docks or broader IPod connectivity. Wifi is available, but costs almost $15/day, reducible to only (?) $10/day by taking a weekly package, and suffers from poor speed and – in some rooms at least – poor signal strength. I gather that the latter is not quite as cynical as it seems, as Mexico suffers from the expensive and poor quality telecoms services that are the result of a poorly regulated quasi-monopoly. Service is generally good, although my initial requests for lightbulbs to be replaced went unanswered. The rooms are of a good size, with desk and armchair, large beds and wardrobs/drawers. Pleasingly, ironing facilities are provided, though – annoyingly – tea and coffee making facilities are not. On the subject of beds – the mattresses appear to be old-style feather ones (as are the pillows) and have a fair bit of “give” in them. The second I slept in was OK, but the first caused some problems for my middle-aged and not entirely healthy back. Of course, renovating a hotel like the Camino – which must be something of a national treasure – presents some issues and needs to be done sensitively. Personally, I wonder if some research aimed at recreating original features in areas such as the bathrooms and the room furnishings might not be the best idea: i.e sell the hotel as something which is a complete time capsule and is as true as possible to the original architect’s vision. Even though that implies retaining the purple carpet in the rooms. But whichever way this is done, modernising the failing electrical and airconditioning systems is a must if the sort of consumer comfort that people want, even at this mid/high price point, is going to be delivered. Bottom line? If you have any interest in architecture, or even just want to stay in a hotel that gives you a sense of place, rather than the anonymous 5 star standard where you don't know what country you're in - you shouldn’t miss the Camino. Just be prepared for a few compromises along the way. Postscript: If you go to their website, you’ll find that this hotel has spawned a chain, as have other famous hotels around the world (eg the Raffles). So make sure it is the Camino Real Polanco you book. Unfortunately, you will get no sense of the architecture from the pictures on offer on the website. But believe me on this score.

Reviews.Title: “On its way down”
Reviews.Author: nic1954
Reviews.Content: This was my third stay at the Camino Real, the first time being round 8-10 years ago. I remember my first visit as being blown away by the cool architecture, the amazing fountain in the entranceway, the bar made out of solid ice in the lobby where they served great martinis. Boy has that all gone now. I arrived at midnight after a 22 hour flight from Singapore and was made to queue for at least 30-40 minutes ot check in. A huge group of conference delegates was checking in ahead of me and only two people were serving at the counter - surely they knew in advance these people were coming. By the way check out was not much faster even though I checked out around 10:30am. I hate to think what it must be like at peak times! The rooms are certainly tired. Like another reviewer, my safe did not work, and the shower seemed to alternate between hot and cold water. Breakfast was a crazy rush of people with a relatively poor choice given the price. WiFi costs 10USD per day in your room and bottled water 4USD. I only ordered room service and to be honest the food as not too bad but there were isues. I ordered Italian salad and got Caprese. My minestrone was luke warm and the pizza a little soggy. My experience of the staff was not as bad as some reviewers. The guy ordering me a taxi was the same one I recall from 3-4 years ago and he was always friendly and helpful. Front desk staff, when oyu finally got to them, were reasonably helpful too. Based on this whole experience though this will be my last visit to Camino Real unless they can really up their game and renovate the whole place to its former standards.

Reviews.Title: “Worst Customer Service in the City of Mexico”
Reviews.Author: WashingtonDCRobert
Reviews.Content: Most of the hotel front desk agents act like robots, they don't care about their guests, From the time I arrived to the hotel, everything was really bad, I wasn't allowed to check-in 20 minutes early due to hotel regulations, in addition they didn't honor my online reservation including original price, bed size, room location,etc. I was forced to move to another floor, they changed my room twice and I didn't get the king bed requested. The staff at the club level didn't resolve the problems, they are young kids with no hotel or work experience.I was forced to wait again almost an hour before I was move to another room. as a result I missed a business meeting due to this situation. I tried to contact the hotel management several times by phone and in person but i was told that no manager was on duty that afternoon. Finally, I was able to locate a senior staff in the lobby area and I complained to her about the whole situation. I just got a weak ans simple "I'm sorry" as a response from that manager that day. The whole front desk staff don't care about the guests needs, I strongly suggest to book your reservations in other hotels with better customer service in the area, Sadly, The Camino Real Hotel Polanco is going down, they overchange you all the time, bad internet connection, dirty pool, mediocre food and terrible customes service. In conclusion, a very dissapointed experience for our travel group, as a result our company canceled all our business at this place. Stay out of this terrible place.

Reviews.Title: “Great Quaint Mexico”
Reviews.Author: adilpereira
Reviews.Content: This place has an old mexico feel and nice large rooms. The showers are amazing and so are the beds. I like the hotel staff hospitality and friendliness. Well located, it is easy to go anywhere. Food is good, portions are huge!

Reviews.Title: “Hidden Fees”
Reviews.Author: Joel G
Reviews.Content: When you asked for a taxi they charged you more than the double. From toluca Airport to Camino Real Polenco with Caminante taxi we paid 510 pesos and from Camino real to Toluca airport 1,3000. Also, each time we asked for a taxi they charged 70 pesos more in Mexico.

Reviews.Title: “Veeeeeerrry nice, comfortable, great location and luxurious ! Oh yes, and great price !!”
Reviews.Author: Majito
Reviews.Content: The price is very cheap for the GREAT things this hotel has to offer... The rooms are very nice, good space and the bed is delicious. The pool and the gardens are relaxing, clean and nice... The restaurants are delicious. Also, it has a great location... You can walk to the shops or dinner places... You will safe in there too. It is true that it needs painting, but still looking very posh and modern... I was going to give 5 stars except for the fact that the shower has a bad design and all the bathroom will get wet.... :-/ One more thing... the employees are very friendly and helpful. I LOVED my stay there and will go back next year !!!

Reviews.Title: “Very very good!”
Reviews.Author: reneemarbella
Reviews.Content: Spacious and nicely furnished, excelent service Good choice of restaurants Great lication

Reviews.Title: “Reputation exceeds reality”
Reviews.Author: CdnTraveller2Go
Reviews.Content: This is no longer a 5 star hotel. The rooms are tired. Fact that safe didn't work treated as if it was common. Light fixture hanging by its cord. One of lights missing bulb. No paper in the morning. Understaffed at breakfast and staff not all that friendly or helpful. Our room was at the back-end and they locked the courtyard which meant a long long walk in the corridor. Surely, a lock operated by the door card could have been installed. On a positive note, the staff on the front desk were more than helpful. The physical facility is basically nice but a refit is needed. the pool was great although at about 40 degrees C, a bit like swimming in a bathtub.

Reviews.Title: “Better than I expected based on some reviews”
Reviews.Author: Quakhunter
Reviews.Content: The hotel was very unusual in its architecture, which was expected, but very warm and in good shape in the common areas. My room was very clean but the carpet was purple, ala Prince Purple Rain days and the other colors more muted. My room was comfortable, as a matter of fact the bed was as comfortable as any bed I've slept in recently. I ate three meals in the hotel at two different restaurants. Food was very good and service was excellent, although pricing was high. I enjoyed my stay and would stay there again. The location in Polanco was safe and the entertainment and food was excellent.

Reviews.Title: “Just don't.”
Reviews.Author: TelegramSam55
Reviews.Content: I've stayed at two fantastic Camino Real hotels in the past, in Oaxaca and Puebla, and so I booked a spontaneous trip here through Orbitz without applying my usual due diligence (i.e., reading multiple customer reviews thoroughly). Plus I've found many travelers allow their negative experiences in Mexico City as a whole to unfairly color their views of individual places so I stupidly dismissed the overall low ratings. In this case however the bad reviews are correct and I now regret being such a lazy snob about the whole thing. Before I get into my specific complaints, let me be general: This is a gigantic, impersonal business/convention-oriented hotel. And if you're into that sort of thing (I'm not), I'm sure you can do much better in Mexico City. The location is not in Polanco, as it says in their name, and you have to cross several busy streets to get there. I'm fairly fit and used to the city's smog, altitude, and traffic and I still found it a haul. Chapultepec Park is across the street, technically, but there's a giant sports complex with high walls separating you from it. You have to walk at least a half mile to find an actual entrance. Like many others, I was partially lured by the architecture, which is unique and somewhat interesting, but the overall effect is a dated, avant garde mega mall. Alienating and very cold, not cool and luxurious as the photos make it out to be. But most of that is subjective. What's not subjective is the the front desk service, which is the worst I've ever encountered. Let me repeat: it's the worst I've ever encountered. We arrived late after booking a "deluxe" room and were given a room on a busy street that stank of smoke. This is a massive hotel and the walk from the lobby to the room was at least a third of a mile -- I'm not joking -- and after a full day's travel I wasn't in the mood to march all the way back. So I called the front desk to ask for a different room and was put on hold. I waited 15 minutes and then hung up and made the trip back anyway. The man behind the desk was courteous yet dismissive, saying his hands were tied because I'd booked through Orbitz. He had no idea what a "deluxe" room was and said the hotel was completely full. Too tired to argue (it was close to midnight), I surrendered but asked if I could have my room changed for the rest of my trip. He said he would make a note and told me to come back in the morning. I went back to my smoky room and ordered a pizza from room service, which frankly wasn't bad, though somewhat lukewarm, likely because of the aforementioned long walk. The TV remote barely worked, there's no art on the walls, and they charge US$4 for the bottled water. After being woken up by loud traffic at 6:00 am (business travelers note: windows are not soundproofed and surrounding streets are loud), I called the front desk and again was put on hold. So I got ready and went to the front desk at 8:00. I was "greeted" gruffly by a distracted, stone-faced young woman. There was no note requesting a room change, so I asked if this could be accomplished, repeating my complaints. She told me to come back at 1:00 pm. Was there any way they could at least confirm a change was possible? No. The hotel was full. ...But then what would change at 1:00? Could they not simply promise me a smoke-free, quieter room? No... Maybe... I don't know. I asked for a manager and instead another desk person of equal rank came to help, slightly friendlier. She said they'd write a note. I told her my last "note" hadn't worked out too well, and explained my frustration. She shrugged her shoulders (literally) and explained there was nothing they could do. I asked for a manager again, and was given one. He at least made eye contact and wasn't attempting to do three other things while attending to me, as the other desk people so far had done. He was apologetic but told me, again, that his hands were tied since the reservation had been made through Orbitz. I told him I'd paid extra for a "deluxe" room and again he told me he had no idea what that meant, but went into a long, convoluted explanation of room types available at the hotel. I told him I simply wanted confirmation I'd be moved to a quiet, smoke-free room, and after some discussion, he "found" another room (in a supposedly full hotel), but said it was still on the street, "but a quiet one." I had taken an early morning hike around the circumference of the property and I assure you, the Camino Real Polanco (actually Anzures) has no such thing adjoining it. I told him I wanted an inside room and after much tapping at his computer console, he told me they were all booked. I told him I was checking out and to cancel the remainder of my reservation, at which point he "found" an inside room but told me I'd have to pay for an upgrade. I told him to cancel the remainder of my reservation and he offered to upgrade me for free. I was tired of Let's Make a Deal, tired of him, tired of the Camino Real and $40 worth of calls to Orbitz later, I was able to check out and receive a refund. The long calls were not due to Orbitz, but because -- yup -- they (and thus we) were on hold for 20 minutes waiting to speak to a (higher-level) manager. Mexico City is a wonderful, fascinating place and Chilangos are some of the friendliest, most charming people on earth. Camino Real must have really had to go out of their way to staff this place with people who are quite the opposite. I usually stay with friends when I'm down there so I don't have any other recommendations for alternatives, but I can't imagine you could do worse in this price range. Stay away.

Reviews.Title: “The worst customer service and thief in the room!”
Reviews.Author: Frequentbusiness76
Reviews.Content: I stayed last week in a business trip with my company and my experience was completely dishonest. Some of my jewelry was taken out of my room, when I returned home most of the jewelry that I always fly with was taken out. Everything was well hidden in a small case, but is no whee to be fined. I called the hotel and no one wanted to take my call after rolling the call with nearly eight people, some type of manager answered me, I did the claim and told me to call back in 5 hours. The worst customer service ever. When I call back, knowing the person name went directly to her and imagine her answer "Was this is the safe, if it was not in the same we are not responsible". What kind of business type hotel hire thieves to work at the hotel. Is the housekeeping staff needed of more money to buy jewelry? I do not recommend at all anyone to stay in this hotel, bad customer services,not recognizing errors and thieves! Go some where else.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent for Architecture Buffs”
Reviews.Author: HotelFanDeluxeYes
Reviews.Content: First time I arrived for check in I was amazed by the 60's modern architecture, it is much more impressive and memorable in person than it is in photographs. I admire it more and more during each stay. Having read a few other guests' reviews, I am reminded how people's opinions can differ significantly: for example, a few reviewers have disliked the darkened hallways enough to comment upon them, but I have always enjoyed the dramatic feel of walking to my room, enjoying the cool dark interiors while looking at the hot humid exterior. One reviewer refers to the hotel's paint job as garish, while I find the strong hispanic colorations to be authentic, dramatic, and utterly perfect for this place. I do alot of business entertaining and my dinner guests have always enjoyed the wide array of good dining options here. I have not been disappointed in my few stays here, and will only caution that it does a huge amount of group meeting business, sometimes the large lobby is filled to the brim with people coming and going.

Reviews.Title: “Will Not Stay Here Again”
Reviews.Author: Businesstraveller200
Reviews.Content: Hi, I come to Mexico twice a month on business staying about a week each time. So I personally bring a lot of business to the hotel industry here. I usually stay at the Four Seasons, given its impeccable service to their business clientele. But I wanted to try something different, and people recommended the Camino Real in Polanco. Frankly, I will never stay here again. While the service was acceptable, the food was not on par and heavy. But the kicker was on my third night, I came back from a business dinner to a steady drumbeat of music I could hear from the top floor. When I called the reception, they said that this music would not stop until 1 a.m.--on a Wednesday night when I had a very important meeting first thing the next morning. When I asked if something could be done, the woman in the reception told me that she'd call the manager and call me back. She never did. If you need sleep while you work, do not stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Spacious room, excellent facilities”
Reviews.Author: Warwickite
Reviews.Content: Excellent guest service & support. Twin room, spacious with beautiful marble bathroom. Room overlooked the internal garden & pool, was quiet at this time of the year but would possibly be noisy in summer. Room service & restaurants were great. Business centre was extra cost. Boutiques/shops within hotel were very good quality. Location is nice & feels safe & excellent drivers available from door. This was a business trip and this hotel was great for the purpose.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid this place until the renovation is complete.”
Reviews.Author: aajwc333
Reviews.Content: I have to stay there occasionally because my employer (major airline) has some sort of contract for crew members to stay there. I've been staying there off and on for the past 10 ten years. The hotel is convenient to walk to from your flight. The interior of the hotel is being renovated. While the renovation is taking place you practically need a hard hat to navigate yourself to your room. I stayed there last night. After a long day of flying you have to drag your luggage up and down steps. The rooms we were given didn't permit us to use the rooms easily accessible to an elevator close to the front desk. (a lot of dragging rollerboards through makeshift tunnels (I'm completely serious) visqueen, drywall, crummy, dusty, dirty nightmare. At least part of the hotel needs to be closed until the renovation is complete. These same rooms you have to navigate to have poor access to wi fi, boxy, choppy , incredible small rooms that force you to use the bathroom in a small closet. Glass doors that separete the toilet and shower from the lavatory. Yuk! Uncomfortable , dogs barking in the middle of the night. Wooden ramps (been there forever and if you're lucky, otherwise you're dragging your bags up and down steps. Accomodating staff usually very friendly.

Reviews.Title: “I didn't like this hotel.”
Reviews.Author: HGfromOmaha
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel for 1 night in August 2011. I checked in around 11PM and had no problems checking in. However, after I received my key, I had to walk around to find the elevators. There seems to be a trend in many International hotels to have darkened hallways to give a more "artsy" look and feel, and that made me uncomfortable. The room was ok. I slept well. I just didn't like the hotel. There were probably 2 English TV channels and the rest were all in Spanish. I can't put my finger on it but I just didn't feel comfortable here.

Reviews.Title: “OK Hotel. Great service however old facilities.”
Reviews.Author: Gorkus
Reviews.Content: The Camino Real Polanco is a big hotel, being the flagship of the Camino Real group in Mexico City. I used to have the coolest and grooviest disco in Mexico City back in the 80's so any local around 50 will have a nice memory of the hotel. The service is outstanding and people are always willing to help. You will always get a smile from someone, that is for sure. Rooms are large however so are the halls and given the size of the building you might find yourself walking a long distance to get down to the Lobby area. Additional elevators would be a good idea (although probably not a realistic possibility due to building limitations). FB outlets are quite OK. Breakfast is abundant and the buffest is well cared for. The downside is the quality of the food, wich is average if not slightly below. Overalll the hotel is nice, comfortable, spacious and charming in its own way. A renovation would be a good idea. I would also improve the quality of the food (only experienced breakfast to be honest). The hotel is so big that checking out can be an issue at rish hour (morning).

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Great Service, Great Memories”
Reviews.Author: charismalito
Reviews.Content: One of the poshest hotels in DF. I stayed here for two months while my girlfriend was working and I studied Spanish. The president of Mexico held a conference here, and I met the roadies for Metallica and probably rubbed elbows with cartel bosses. The wait staff were very friendly, at first they were professional and cold but once I started joking around with them they would greet me as if I was coming to my own home each day. I kind of felt like I had the run of the place! Internet service is a rip off, I ended up buying an air card because it was cheaper in the long run. The crowd that stays here is kind of stuck up... then again you are in Polanco. The sushi restaurant was as good as you would expect in Mexico City, the spanish restaurant was expensive and poor quality. We ordered room service most nights, and it was usually decent quality. For a good meal hire a vocho to take you to nearby Puerto Madera!! There is also a aqua lounge in the lobby and really cool nightclub upstairs that the well to do hangout at if you dont want to venture down to Condeza. They have daily cleaning and nightly turn down service. The hotel itself is only 4 stories high so you can hear the hustle and bustle of DF down below such as the street vendors selling food, cars, etc but then again you are in DF and this is part of its charm. A great hotel if you have the money to hang out in Polanco. I had a lot of great memories here!

Reviews.Title: “Tries for more glitz than it can deliver”
Reviews.Author: Timon88
Reviews.Content: I'm sure this property looked fabulous in the '60's, or whenever it was built, but the garish color scheme, sprawling layout, dingy hallways and "modern" design have not withstood the test of time particularly well. Many rooms smell of mold--there are some serious insulation and waterproofing issues. The front desk is a mess of disorganization--the simplest question requires at least a 20-minute wait. It's located in what is essentially a suburb, a bit far from most things the average tourist would want to do. Still, it's decently comfortable--there's much worse out there.

Reviews.Title: “surely a great choice”
Reviews.Author: Orlando14
Reviews.Content: A very beautiful hotel in an amazing city. Rooms are big and all comfortable, quite hotel, with nearby facilities. Personnel always at fast disposal very careful in details. Wonderful beds, huge bathrooms and a particular mention to the fitness rooms, with a tapis roulant and full triaining tools The hotel has a wide range of choice for shops and restaurant, all great quality and interesting prices. A place to go, to enjoy Mex city and its beauties

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel with some service problems”
Reviews.Author: divezuzu
Reviews.Content: Location is great. We stayed for a week as part of a conference. Friendly staff, clean rooms, small but nice bathrooms. Two problems we encountered: first was noise. We were in an "outside" room with very nice views but the traffic and barking dogs noise kept us up all night. Also the hair dryer didn't work and I reported that. We were moved to an "inside room" the next day which was a great improvement noise-wise. It was a smaller room but still nice. And guess what - the hair dryer didn't work in this room either. I reported the hair dryer issue again to the front desk and was assured there would be a working hair dryer in the room in time for a big evening social event we had to attend. Sure enough there was another hair dryer in the room but my mistake was not checking it before taking a shower. Third strike out and I'm stuck with wet hair and another nonworking hair dryer. This time I went to the front desk (with wet hair) and said I was waiting right there until I got a "working" hair dryer. Finally one was brought to the front desk with an apology and a smile. The breakfast buffet is really nice with lots of options and the staff always friendly. Just check out the hairdryers before taking a shower.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: TruthMexicoCity
Reviews.Content: Stayed there for a week during a business trip.. Have seen the hotel for ages, but never actually stayed there. It was a pleasant stay, with the exception of check in/out procedures, which were possibly some of the slowest I have ever experienced, although staff was very polite and fresh. Rooms are a bit dated, but perfectly clean and excellently maintained. Brown marble mirrored bathrooms are huge and extremely nice looking, and the shower is a marvel. If you have a lower floor room, you may find it a bit noisy, but this is a lively hotel with very nice and trendy restaurants/bars, so you know what to expect... Location is good, although the hotels deeply into Polanco are better located if your purpose is more business oriented, if you go on a holiday, its a very good try... Parking is extremely expensive, but all Polanco hotelsÂ´ parkings are an insult. Good but expensive Wifi Internet as well. Sometimes the CR has very good rates, especially for weekends. Yes, a bit complicated to get to the down-staired lobby when arriving/leaving carrying your luggage.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel but expensive restautants and stairs to get in and out of the lobby.”
Reviews.Author: Bkog
Reviews.Content: Very nice hotel. Worth the extra money to get a Club room to get an inward facing courtyard room that is quiet, includes continental breakfast, supper snacks, alcohol drinks etc and bottled water to go. Service is great, and all staff are very friendly and helpful. Example, I was going to take the Touribus for 125 pesos but I could not get on because it was overcrowded, so the hotel arranged a English speaking guide with a car to drive me for 2 hours to the downtown sites for 600 peso. Great restaurants in the hotel but very expensive e.g. breakfast buffet is 240 pesos (approx $23). Another gripe is that the lobby is a dozen stairs down and you have to go up those stairs every time you want to leave - unless you go out the back entrance which looks more seedy. Try Vips restaurant 4 blocks away for good Mexican food at lower prices.

Reviews.Title: “Nice conference structure and meeting rooms, old and a bit dark rooms.”
Reviews.Author: marcel_sakr
Reviews.Content: Good meeting rooms. Although we were at the basement, they had a good indirect lighting and mirrors that looked like a window at a first quick glance. There were happening several different conferences at the same time... the lobby was always busy... but their good structure and staff made it work without problems. The room that I stayed was old and a bit dark (the downside). But one colleague stayed on a much nicer room, renewed and even with a small balcony. The pool area seems nice, and there's a very good china restaurant along with a 24h bistro and other bars (that seem to host private birthday parties full of young people - don't worry about the noise, the rooms are far away) and restaurants. The bar at this china place have nice appetizers as well (very good crab cakes!).

Reviews.Title: “Great facility and location, no interest in good service”
Reviews.Author: travellingband
Reviews.Content: I have stayed here several times, and the level of service has badly gone downhill. Too often, there is a lack of attention to guests, staff pays no attention to the most obvious requests, and no oversight on the part of management. Note that when I checked out, I objected to nearly $300 of extra charges that should not have been billed, and had them taken off. I complained to the front desk manager, who assured me that all my complaints would be addressed in a call or email from the general manager within 24 hours. Note that I am still waiting three days later....

Reviews.Title: “Excellent hotel if you get a quiet room”
Reviews.Author: WeekendHussler
Reviews.Content: This hotel ticks the important boxes for me: clean, quiet, safe, and a good sleep. My room was very clean and the bathroom was a pretty standard for a Western 4-star hotel. However, a number of my colleagues have mentioned that their rooms were quite noisy with either traffic or music so I suggest that you ask for a quiet room upon check-in. Which brings me to the next point: the check-in/check-out process takes an extraordinarily long time; hence you often see a long queue in the lobby. I'm not sure why hotels don't invest in systems to allow for a quick process because this is the second impression for guests (after the lobby). There are plenty of restaurants and bars so you're sure to find something to your taste (and price). You can also walk out the front of the hotel; turn right; and walk about 100 meters to a convenience store but seek advice regarding safety (I felt very comfortable during the day). If you have patience for a long check-in time (then again, you might get lucky), I would highly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel rooms need a total makeover”
Reviews.Author: ThoughtfulTraveler05
Reviews.Content: This hotel, supposedly a 4 star, had the worst hotel room I have stayed in for a long time. The room stank, and so every day the maids sprayed it and all other rooms with a noxious smelling air freshener to cover the smell. The furniture was dirty and beaten up, and looked to be 20 years old. While the public areas are nice, the conference rooms are also old and smelly. Finally, the restaurants that I tried (2) are over priced and the food mediocre at best. For the money, there are much better choices in the Polanco area.

Reviews.Title: “Good and bad”
Reviews.Author: Lacemaker
Reviews.Content: I was attending a week long conference with people from all over the world. First impressions when I arrived late at night and very tired were, amazing public spaces, friendly reception staff and huge wide corridors. As the week went on I found two staff in particular very helpful Victor and Ishmael who provided answers to numerous questions and gave maps and directions (perfect service). Some of the down points. Internet connection was both expensive and appalling - most of my fellow delegates had the same problems. I had cash stolen from my purse and a colleague had cash taken from his bedside table (both smallish amounts). We are both to blame for leaving the cash out of the safe however I was very upset to know that someone had rifled through my handbag. Hotel reaction was poor and handled badly. So please ensure all of your valuables go into the safe at all times! Breakfast was fantastic and the staff efficient and helpful. I used the pool in the dark every morning and it was very pleasant (the altitude meant I had trouble sleeping). Like another reviewer I had a very dark room looking onto a wall and in retrospect I really should have insisted on being moved. The hotel is in a fantastic location so do try and get out and walk as much as possible. Just such a huge city it is hard to comprehend how anyone gets around in the traffic!

Reviews.Title: “Colorful Adventures at Camino Real”
Reviews.Author: Simple_Country_Boy
Reviews.Content: Visited this brightly-hued "modern" hotel by starchitect Ricardo Legorreta with a tour group interested in Modern Architecture. Stayed for 7 nights. This large property is suprisingly difficult to navigate with spread-out wings and no maps. Some rooms had green courtyard views - but not mine. I got a street-side room with a view of a power pole. Opening the curtains on my dowdy patio was necessary to get some light into my unusually dark room. The room and bath (good mirrors but tepid "hot" water) were large with bright colors and wood accents. The breakfast buffet - with juices, cereals, breads and fruits - met my needs. Disappointments included: 1. street noise required closing off patio sliding door for sleeping which required 2. turning on A/C for cooling which leaked really cold water onto floor by bath entrance 3. power failure - only in closet - stranded valuables in "safe" To their credit, hotel management tried to respond to problems 2 & 3. I prefer a hotel where my first room doesn't require correction.

Reviews.Title: “Cool hotel !”
Reviews.Author: Geemiker
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 2 days in May 2010. The hotel is located in a nice neighborhood. During our stay they we renovating a lot of rooms and this gave a bit of a mess at the pool area. Also on our floor the renovation was going on. Besides this, the overall atmosphere of this place is relaxed. The hotel accommodates some nice restaurants like the Asiatic influenced China Grill. The rooms are very spacious and well equipped. The king bed was very comfortable. Check-in and check-out isn't the most quick one, but overall a very cool and nice hotel. I would highly recommend this place to any leisure or business traveller.

Reviews.Title: “Great choice for exploring Chapultepec Park with children”
Reviews.Author: Maria-Tucson
Reviews.Content: Built in 1968, with an architectural style that gives you the impression of spaciousness and simplicity, the hotel is just beautiful and comfortable. Our double-bed room at "La Palma" section had lots of space, balcony facing one of the beautiful courtyards with a pool, and a large bathroom (no bathtub, but shower was very roomy). We only wished the shower head had more flexibility for setting your desired output of water. In terms of service, the hotel staff thrived to offer you a friendly useful service immediately. They answered all of our questions, attended our requests and gave us useful information in an efficient quick manner. The hotel also changed towels and cleaned up the bathroom and beds as soon as we would leave our room in the morning and again in the evening. We had late dinner a couple of nights at one of their restaurants, La Huerta. The food was excellent, but be aware that they are more expensive that some of the restaurants you can find nearby. The hotel was full of activity day and night, so you may hear in the middle of the night young professionals going back to their rooms. The area surrounding the restaurant seemed to be safe for strolling at night, but the amount of traffic on Escobedo Street made us a bit nervous when crossing intersections at night with two children. The Camino Real Polanco was a good choice to access by foot Chapultepec Park with the kids during the day, via the pedestrian pathway the goes underneath the street Paseo de la Reforma, so we felt pretty safe with the children and traffic then, and were very glad we didn't rent a car!

Reviews.Title: “Set expectations accordingly”
Reviews.Author: 767DriverTexas
Reviews.Content: The hotel was very average for Mexico - certainly not a luxury hotel. Staff was friendly, but the hotel (at least my room) was very run down. Shower had very little pressure, 2 lights didnt work, the room had a horrible sewer type smell and the furnishings were in very bad shape. When I left the room, the door handle broke off in my hand. I told the front desk and they didnt seem too surprised. Oh well - it was only one night - glad I wasnt personally responsible for the bill - too expensive for what you get.

Reviews.Title: “Location Location”
Reviews.Author: lhache
Reviews.Content: Walk to subway, 5 minutes, then you are off to anywhere in the city, and outside! Staff is fantastic and everyone is gregarious. Clean to perfection. Right up on Chapultepec Bosque, with many eateries and quick snack places nearby. Safe at night to walk to and from Subway, Restaurants in Hotel Magnificent, and prices of meals, affordable! Windows open for fresh air. Huge shower stalls. Few english channels. Gym and pool fantastic. Great to come home to after much shopping and eating and sightseeing.

Reviews.Title: “Not up to business travel standards”
Reviews.Author: DAMR
Reviews.Content: I spent 10 days with some colleagues at the Caminon Real Polanco. I must say that although I did not expected much of it (having read some reviews before I arrived), I was disappointed by it, for the following reasons : - The rooms are quite small, and dark. Their walls are painted in a yellow - brown color which is rather depressing, and did not help me relax after a day of work. The TV is old and the reception not very good. - the bathroom is not very convenient : you cannot set the strength of the shower so you cannot prevent water from going everywhere. Besides, there must have been a problem with the sewer because I was woken up 2 nights in a row by a very strong smell coming out from the shower. I had to let water flow for a few minutes and lock the door of the bathroom in order to get back to sleep. - the staff at the reservation offce was down right stubborn : they refused to let us leave for a week end and keep our rate (we were supposed to stay 1 month, and intended to leave Mexico City for 1 or 2 week-ends). So after 2 days trying to negociate, as we couldn't even talk to the sales manager, we just cancelled our reservation and left for the Hotel Nikko which is much much better. Otherwise, the breakfast was good, but expensive (235 pesos, approximately 20 $). There are many restaurants, which is convenient, but be aware that they are quite expensive. The global architecture of the hotel is nice, but somewhat too big : the reception is so wide and crowdy it gives you the impression of being in a train station hall. The inner patio with the swimming pool was very relaxing, though.

Reviews.Title: “Not up to business travel standards”
Reviews.Author: Gueyis
Reviews.Content: I have stayed in the Camino Real in Polanco on several occasions and have normally had relatively good experiences. Their staff for the most part is friendly and accommodating and the service has been above par. While the hotel product is dated and needs refurbishment, the rooms are spacious and the ones facing the garden are quiet. One of several comments I have is the design of the hotel is not accommodating to people with handicaps or people carrying suitcases - there are steps everywhere and virtually no ramps. To get from the guest rooms to many of the restaurants one has to take an elevator to the lobby then go up several flights of stairs - there is no way to access the restaurants by elevator from the guest rooms. With the 24/7 global nature of the world now, this upscale hotel in a major world city also needs to start catering to those hours. The gym for example closes at 10 PM and the pool closes at 7. Most gyms at least in major city hotels are open 24/7 and the pools are open at least until 10 if not 24/7 as well (with key access only after a certain hour). The worst evidence of this was on my stay there earlier this month. For some reason, the wireless internet in my room went down after I came back from dinner (it had been working earlier). After several rebooting attempts to no avail I called the front desk to see if I could get a cable and try that way. It took them over 45 minutes to find a cable for me - something which should be a standard fixture in the room in any case. When that didn't work I asked to speak to tech support and was told that there was no one at the hotel who could help me at that hour (it was around midnight). When I asked if they didn't have a 24/7 tech support call line, I was told they did not. This was unacceptable to me as I had about 2 hours of ahead of me as I work with India which was in the middle of their day. I spoke with the Manager on Duty and said that this was unacceptable. He came to my room to see if he could fix the problem and was also somehow able to contact a tech support person (even though supposedly there was no one available at that hour) who also tried to fix the problem and was also unable to fix the problem. We tried different guest rooms to see if that helped and I still had the same problem. When I asked if anyone else had complained about the internet they said no but it could also be because by that time it was getting close to 1 AM. As a last ditch effort we took my computer to the lobby to see if I could have computer access in the lobby and lo and behold it worked. So 2 1/2 hours after I had first called with the problem I was finally able to access the internet. I spent from 1:30-3:30 AM sitting at the guest relations desk answering e-mails (there was also another guest in the lobby doing the same thing) and ended up getting just 4 hours of sleep before my long work day. The Manager on Duty asked what they could do to compensate for the inconvenience and I asked for permission to use the Executive Floor lounge which he did give me. However, after the frustrations of the evening I as hoping I would have had note from the general manager waiting for me in my room the next day - but nothing more was done. The hotel needs to gear up for today's world where business is conducted around the clock. They need to have access to tech support that is able to help anytime night or day, have cables available in the rooms if the wireless does not work and have longer hours in the gym and pool. They also need to redisgn the hotel to make access easier with small suitcases - where we don't necessarily need the services of the bell staff-and also to people with disabilities. I also think they need to do a better job of customer service to their clients when inconveniences do occur.

Reviews.Title: “the Moon Bar was good but I feel sure there must be more attractive venues in Mexico City.”
Reviews.Author: SeriousTraveller01
Reviews.Content: The attached â€œoutdoor gardenâ€� Moon Bar was a disappointment, a poor imitation of others around the world. The techno music was good, plus some chart singles with videos, but the video quality had extremely poor definition. The actual sky was not visible due to a cover which may or may not be retractable, however the surrounding buildings are not attractive so perhaps better to keep the Moon Bar enclosed. The atmosphere in the Moon Bar was good but I feel sure there must be more attractive venues in Mexico City.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice hotel,”
Reviews.Author: BryanJJordan
Reviews.Content: very nice, in every respect. Too many security guards for my taste (one every few feet, but otherwise awesome

Reviews.Title: “Good location - thatÂ´s it”
Reviews.Author: JoachimG
Reviews.Content: I stayed during a trade show for the first time in this hotel. As the location is convenient to the show, I booked there. To me the hotel is by far too big. 700 rooms. The rooms and bathrooms are already quite old and need some renovation. If you are unlucky you get a quite noisy room. The first room I was in, then I claimed and got a quite room. The only good thing was the fast and reliable room service with good qualtiy food. Internet WiFi is not for free, you got to pay 24h.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: Cargenty
Reviews.Content: My hsband was invite me 2 days a mexico . he stay for bussiness and he choose this hotel because is very close ti his mexico's office. I loved this hotel. very nice decorations, Big room with a nice terrace and very clean. The service is perfect and the restaurant La huerta excelent. The breakfast (included in the price) was huge. I hope comeback ans stay more days with my family.

Reviews.Title: “Tried and true favorite”
Reviews.Author: bbc001
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel to unwind for a few days before continuing on a vacation that would be less relaxing and more exploring. We had stayed at this hotel in the past and we were not disappointed. The service is always excellent, the rooms, although not luxurious are elegant and are always clean and well stocked. The club rooms are especially nice because you can go get breakfast, a snack or a drink without leaving your floor. The pool and terrace are wonderful, and with 7 restaurants the choices for meals are endless.

Reviews.Title: “Good business hotel but one serious incident”
Reviews.Author: rafkam
Reviews.Content: I chose this hotel for a first trip to Mexico with my fiancÃ©e. Not knowing anything about the city, I deemed it to be well located for the main sights and dining and entertainment. The hotel was also on a good rate, which is why I chose an executive room, which featured larger rooms and access to the executive lounge. Check-in was fairly trouble-free, on the 5th floor at the executive lounge. Upon check-in for the executive rooms, you get free complimentary dry-cleaning and shoe shining service, which was a welcome perk after trudging my work clothes on our holiday to Mexico and in preparation for my meetings the next day. Other perks include complimentary breakfast buffet at the lounge (somewhat small selection, but adequate) and afternoon drinks and snacks, which were very good. The hotel itself is very interesting architecturally and has striking bars and outdoor areas. The swimming pool area is also very nice. Our room was massive, with possibly the largest bed Iâ€™ve ever seen in a hotel. The room was also quiet, and you could keep the windows open and still hear limited noise from the street. Bathroom was nice, with a good selection of toiletries. All was going very well until the time we were returning to our room after dinner on the second nice. As we were heading towards the elevators a security guy stopped us in order to check that we were guests. Until then, I thought ok, itâ€™s a security spot check. I gave him our room number and surname, which he found on his printout. At that point I thought heâ€™d thank us, but no, he scanned the sheet until he found the number of guests in the room: 2, and only then did he let us go! I found this completely unacceptable as it implied he thought my fiancÃ© might have been a prostitute. To make matters worse, as he was â€œquestioningâ€� us, loads of other (male) guests were walking past unchallenged. He specifically picked on us as we were a couple! This brings me to another question: is this hotel so sleazy they feel the need to check if every good looking young woman is a prostitute? I canâ€™t see any other reason for the â€œrandomâ€� check. The next morning I complained to the manager at the executive lounge and was given the typical â€œweâ€™re doing this for your securityâ€�. Then why not check on the male guests!? Needless to say, Iâ€™ve knocked 3 stars off on account of this otherwise good hotel. And next time Iâ€™m in Mexico Iâ€™ll look at staying in a smaller, friendlier hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Place But.........”
Reviews.Author: ord737fo
Reviews.Content: I stay here on business all the time. This place is really nice outside and safe and right in town and you CAN drink the water there and the lobby is nice and the gym is great and the pool is great BUT the housekeeping people never seem to be able to get the rooms right. Either you get all the coffee in the world and no coffee maker, or 3 hand creams and no shampoo or something like that. It seems trivial but when you are trying to shower and don't have things you expect to its kind of aggravating. Be sure to have your own stash of supplies before you go. They have Hi Speed internet but it's $20 and the Brakfast buffet is also $20. Walk 3 blocks outside to the VIPS restaurant and have the same thing for $5.80. (Its like a Dennys) Also I found this really bad electrical connection under the sink last time I was there. This is not good......

Reviews.Title: “Location - location location”
Reviews.Author: DonHector
Reviews.Content: Perfect location in Mexico City, right across the Mexico DF - Benito Juarez Airport...we returned from a short visit to Cuernavaca. Had an early flight so we came the day before to avoid waking up at 3AM. The room was clean and comfortable. The front is a bit slow at check in but once you are in the room the location is perfect. Concierges are very nice and helped us secured transportation the the Basilica de la Virgen de Guadalupe (a must if you are a Catholic), we also visited the Zocalo (Mexico main place across from the Presidential Palace). Beware never ever flagged taxis in Mexico city, a friend of ours was robbed on her way to her hotel. You are better off taking and paying for the cab in the airport (they have a kiosk to pay for your ride plus it helps tracking with cab you take)...SAFE and affordable. This is not a 5 star hotel but a high 3 close to a 4...will be a safe bet, specially if you need a place to sleep for an early flight.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel in an Excellent Location”
Reviews.Author: sllydderrr
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed here for two nights, January 9-11, 2009. This was our first experience in Mexico City so we thought a large hotel near some cultural facilities would be ideal. We wanted to save a few bucks after spending two weeks in Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands and this place was just the ticket. The hotel was built in 1968. For such an old hotel it is in exceptionally good condition. There are six restaurants, a few shops and a huge comfortable lobby. There are over 700 rooms so be prepared to walk! We arrived early and our room was not ready. No big deal we thought, so we left our bags with the concierge and went for lunch. The buffet was quite nice albeit quite expensive. We paid about $75 for lunch for the two of us, at a buffet! Our room was ready exactly when we were told it would be. We had a nice gentleman show us to our room which was great. We would have been lost without him. Not to worry though, once you have been shown the way it is easy to find your way later. He then brought our bags and showed us all the features of the room. The room was a decent size with a large all-marble bathroom. The carpet and bedspread were 'vintage' otherwise the room was nice. The bed was a modern pillow-top, fortunately only the bedspread and throw pillows were old. This is a business hotel at a good price but you will pay dearly for the extras. I didn't mind this as I knew it would happen. The room is a good value and you pay for the extras, rather than paying a lot for the room and having a lot of "free" services. The food at the hotel is good but pricey. Room service was excellent but you pay $15 for a burger or clubhouse. Pepsi is $3.00 for a 355 mL can, etc. An unsecured Wireless B network is available in the rooms for $173 Pesos per 24 hour period. Again this is primarily a business hotel, so most folks just expense such 'necessary' things. As is typical in Mexico you tip for everything. When the people are friendly, courteous and don't appear phony I don't mind this. The Camino Real staff were all first class. Chapultepec Park is across the street. You must walk to the lights at the corner to access it but it is a short walk. There are many museums and such at the park including the famous Museum of Anthropology. This is a great option for the first-time visitor to a city as large and intimidating as Mexico City.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at Camino Real”
Reviews.Author: travelomnewyork
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Camino Real for 5 nights in December with my 3yr old and my husband. we had a very comfortable stay. I don't know what people are saying when they say 3rd world quality - clearly they haven't been to a third world quality hotel!! Camino Real was great! especially with my 3yr old. the room was large and they even brought a real crib into the room - not your typical pack n play that you get even in a Hilton in the States. THe location was perfect if you want to do some sightseeing, plus the restaurants in the hotel are fabulous. We dined at the Castello and the Bonita and loved the food in both the places. It was nice not to have to go out after a whole day of walking! Its walking to distance to Chatulpec park, museum of anthropology and many other touristy sites on the reforma. We even used their pool which was clean and heated and they have a well-equipped gym as well. The best thing about this hotel was their customer service. Room service never took more than 15 mins and all the staff are extremely courteous and friendly. Highly recommended!

Reviews.Title: “Large business hotel”
Reviews.Author: BickleNZ
Reviews.Content: In Mexico City for a conference and was booked here for 10 days and even over that time never really appreciated how many facilities the hotel had. The start was not good being given a room at 0100 that somebody else already occupied (thankfully chained) but resulted in an upgrade so some consolation. Otherwise the experience was mostly upside though with so many event rooms many functions were being held simultaneously and weddings and conferences don't really go together especially when sharing the same entry points and common areas. Service was polite and effective with plenty of staff milling around though whether anything productive was being done by all of them was debatable. Room service was of a high standard and the cleaning ladies really kept the rooms tidy and replenished. The surrounding area was safe but a limited range of restaurants if you wanted to eat out though within a short taxi ride around the Hard Rock Cafe plenty of quality eateries existed. Tap water appeared to be safe to drink which was a bonus given a lack of water coolers within the hotel. With so many hotel rooms and function rooms close by, noisy parties did disturb late into the evening so be aware of rooms close to those functions areas, even the suites. Overall a very acceptable option as a business hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Unique creative hotel, not your cookie cutter business hotel”
Reviews.Author: brownbeer
Reviews.Content: From the wave-generating fountain in the front of the hotel, to the bold color scheme and creative architectural lay out, I imagine that you'll either love it or hate it. I loved it. If you are into single hallway, predictable spaces and the same old bar scene, this is not for you. The owners have accentuated the quirkiness of the hotels features to make it a memorable stay. In the main lobby, there is a "blue" bar off to the right, down the steps is the spacious check-in area. Yes, it take a few minutes to get your bearings, and yes, chances are good you'll get turned around a little, but I find this fun. In fact, two of us stumbled into a bar on the 3rd floor that we had no idea existed. At midnight, the place was hopping with locals and guests alike, the bartenders were engaging and we had a really nice time soaking in the atmosphere. I doubt the same could be said for a Marriott or Hilton. The room itself was large (3rd floor). I was initially followed to my room by a hooker who quickly went away after a brief description of what she could do for (to) me. The encounter was not threatening and in fact, I saw her trolling later in the Blue Bar near the lobby. The bathroom was fantastic, all stone tile with a large shower and sink area. Plenty of amenities as well. The bed was comfortable There was a solid work area with Wifi and the TV worked just fine. There was one lightbulb out but I just don't get excited about things like that. I'm sure if I asked, someone would have changed it. If I had to complain, I'd say the hotel was austere and slightly dark in some areas. Nevertheless, I think it's a neat place to stay and plan on bringing my family there in the event we visit MC in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: KOKUSAIKOKU
Reviews.Content: I loved my stay at the Camino Real. I didn't know where to stay and I am so happy I made the right decision when booking this hotel. I has an excellent location, right in the middle of everything. After all the options I had, this hotel came out to be a deluxe hotel with hight quality service hosting international recognized restaurants for dining. Rate is not that high and you get more for what you pay. If you donÂ´t know where to stay in Mexico City, this is a highly recomended option. Roxanna from Illinois

Reviews.Title: “A Distinctive Choice in DF”
Reviews.Author: buttery
Reviews.Content: We were very pleased with our two stays (summer 2007 and summer 2008) at the Camino Real in Mexico City. It has the amenities you'd find at most other major business hotels - WIFI, gym (stocked with cool fruit juices in the mornings), several restaurants, 3 phones, and spacious marble bathrooms in each room. But there are two reasons we'll continue to choose the Camino Real over equivalent hotels: 1. The location, right between 2 colonias, offers an ideal mix -- between the very upscale Colonia Polanco, home to the major European designers boutiques and numerous Starbucks Coffee outlets (with valet parking, no less), and the more lived-in Colonia Anzures, with its neighborhood taquerias, bustling cantinas, and other local businesses. We spent time walking around in both, and enjoyed the quite different experiences each had to offer. The hotel is also just across the street from Chapultapec Park, and an easy walk to the Tamayo and Modern Art Museums. 2. Style. Unlike the tasteful beige universe you'll encounter at most other top-level hotels, the Camino Real draws on design and architectural elements from Mexican culture, and makes a strong style statement - one that, admittedly, might not be to everyone's taste. The common areas and rooms are decorated in Mexico's vibrant pinks, blues, and yellows, and silver and natural wood play leading roles as well in the decor. At the same time, the hotel isn't perfect. WIFI isn't cheap (with taxes, about 150pesos per day), and the carpeting and window fixtures have seen happier days. During one of our stays, we had some issues with local calling, which took about 2-3 days for them to resolve. We also found the breakfasts to be a poor value, unless you're traveling with an expense account or really must have an American-style buffet breakfast. Instead, we enjoyed the very clean, European-style Pasteleria Alcazar (across from the back entrance, on Leibnitz) for coffee/espresso and a wide selection of pastries, or, for a more traditional hearty Mexican breakfast, Los Panchos (two short blocks south, on Tolstoi). Weekend rates at the hotel are a particularly good value.

Reviews.Title: “1st World Pricing for 3rd World Quality”
Reviews.Author: bedfordave
Reviews.Content: Problems with the room: - Broken lamp shade. - 3 burnt-out lights (out of 6 total). - A funny sewer smell in the bathroom. - Minibar refrigerator was broken (did not refrigerate). - Rug had noticable stains and had a 4ft long rip in it. - Comforters were stained. - Wireless was so slow you couldn't use it, and it cost $10 USD per day! Most hotels include wireless at no additional fee, and it works. Asked to see other rooms after check-in and noticed that each one had similar problems. I would NOT recommend this hotel to anyone unless they dramatically reduced their rates, or renovated the rooms. The building and grounds were nice, but the rooms were about what you would expect from a Howard Johnson Motor Lodge.

Reviews.Title: “It has really disapointed me”
Reviews.Author: MacRobertson
Reviews.Content: This WAS a very goog choice for Mexico City. Value for money. Not anymore. It's getting worst everytime. Last week I was there. Lots of noise in the room, bathroom was NOT clean, some things did not work and some others were broken. I had already started to notice these problems in my last visits, but they've really got worst in a short period of time. But the most unconceivable of all was what happened Sunday morning. Light in the bathroom was gone, I had to do everything in the dark (shower, etc). Nobody able to help. It remained like that until check out, but what a wonderful surprise! The hotel lobby, which is huge, was also in the darkness, and nobody seemed to care! It'd been like that for hours (I learned that later), so I checked out in the darkness, which felt like a joke, a big big disapointment, specially when I asked the person who was attending me -what was happening??? And she said, as naturally as possible, we're having the power plant beign fixed. And that was all, not a smile, not an apology, nothing! Can you believe it? This hotel, which is supposed to be one of the best hotels in the city, has now that face, the face of mediocrity and rudeness.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it”
Reviews.Author: traveler1111
Reviews.Content: I just spent six nights at the Camino Real. Architecture buffs will enjoy Ricardo Legorreta's masterful design with vivid colors. The Blue Lounge, a bar floating on water, is a wonderful experience. My room on the fifth floor with the excutive lounge was lovely except that the windows did not keep out pool noise. This was annoying when I had to listen to a very loud Sat. night wedding ceremony the night before my early departure. Still, however, poolside rooms with balconies seem to be the best choices. The only restaurant I tried was the Spanish one. Several of the other restaurants are pricy chains. I'd recommend trying places in the area instead. The location is terrific. Right across from Chapultepec Park and several important museums. Chic shopping opportunities are nearby.

Reviews.Title: “Modern, crowded and pricey for the value delivered”
Reviews.Author: PMTexas
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel during a business trip (2 days) and the company I work for picked it for a seminar (75 people). But I will talk about my experience as a guest only. Pros: Hotel looks like brand-new, shinning and having a very modern and beautiful decoration. Rooms are relatively spacious (for 1 person) and clean. Hotel buffet restaurant serves tasty food for a fair price. Cons: Hotel Internet reservation system did not work for me. Even showing them my reservation confirmation slip, My friend and I got a room by chance, because the room we picked on-line was not available at the time. The frondesk lady told me to make the reservation by phone next time (!?) My friend had bad luck and ended up dumped in a smoking room. Anyway, my room smelled bad as well because some kind of chemicals they use to clean the rooms. It is really strong! Internet is very well paid and painfully slow. Such a disappointment for a hotel targeting businessmen like that (huge crowds in a huge hotel). Well, for the quality of the room and the hotel itself, room fees are extremely high, compare to other ones in the region. Check-in and check-out services are really bad and slow. I do not know it is a Mexican thing - slowness - or this particular hotel service is just lazy. Front desk people look green and disoriented as well.

Reviews.Title: “All flash but not that great”
Reviews.Author: jloudercp
Reviews.Content: Camino Real is in a beautiful building with very unique architecture and a very spacious lobby and conference space. However, it's not very practical as it is confusing to get around the enormous lobby. The concierge was surprisingly unhelpful and rude, and the cardkeys to the rooms were reset so often that one had to approach the reception desk several times a day to have the key reactivated. Because the hotel is so large this involved many 10 minute walks from the desk to the elevator, elevator to the room, and back again. There are several beautiful restaurants, and one that is open 24 hours, where the food is decent. However, it can be very noisy when the many business travelers who stay there congregate in the lobby and sound travels through all that marble space. Very interesting and artistic layout, especially the ocean-like fountain outside the front entrance. The cleaning staff and transportation staff were extremely helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Great second option for Mexico City”
Reviews.Author: HollyWorton
Reviews.Content: When in DF, I always stay at the Fiesta Americana, but on my last trip I waited until the last minute as always to book, and this time it was full, so I went for the next-closest hotel, which was the Camino Real. Food: the great thing about this hotel is that it has several restaurants, so thereâ€™s a huge variety of options, and the room service menu includes a little from each restaurant. The La Huerta restaurant has amazing breakfasts. I have breakfast here sometimes even when I stay at the Fiesta Americana. I was lucky to get one of the rooms on the fifth floor, which have been remodeled and are pretty nice. A year or so ago, I was shown one of the older rooms and I really couldnâ€™t imagine staying there. Check before you book to see what type of room youâ€™re going to get. The great thing about this room compared to the FA is that they have this HUGE desk, big enough for two people to work at. The service was excellent. The gym is pretty good, except thereâ€™s no stair stepper, which is really important to me. Also, thereâ€™s no spa, or sauna, or steam room, which is disappointing, and a big plus for the Fiesta Americana. I still think Iâ€™d go back to the FA on my next trip to DF, but the Camino Real is definitely a great second option.

Reviews.Title: “camino real a bit disappointed”
Reviews.Author: karla014
Reviews.Content: My family and I booked a 6 day vacation on this hotel, mainly becouse many of our friends and relatives recommended to us, and it is a very impressive hotel, big and bold, It has some of the best restaurants in mexico city , but the rooms are another story... we were assigned one of the rooms that haven't been renovated, it wasn't what we expected, the second day we asked to be changed and they did changed us, the new room was better but we really expected a beautiful room since camino real its an hotel chain with lots of prestige in mexico, so they really need to improve the rooms to keep up with the rest of the chain. Also the service (maids, room service and housekeeping) were slow so our overall experience was good not excellent as we expected.

Reviews.Title: “Nice property but a bit weathered”
Reviews.Author: mattnstacy
Reviews.Content: They have some very large rooms in the 'vip' section of the hotel, with patios, 2 levels, etc. Some of the bathroom materials and fixtures could have used an upgrade, but the hotel is about 40 years old. Be sure and wear long pants to the 'concierge' floor where there is free breakfast, etc. Some of their surly staff can ask you to leave because you are not wearing long pants (even though I was on my way to the gym and wanted to stop in for an OJ).

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed the Hotel Camino Real, Mexico City”
Reviews.Author: artnuvo
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Camino Real, DF, near Chapultepec Park, for 3 days before Christmas and 2 days after, venturing to Mansion del Bosque, San Miguel de Allende for 2 days in between and the subject of a separate review. In this 5 star rated, 4-5* quality hotel, we had a deluxe King room with balcony on the 5th/club or Executive Room floor with a rate that included breakfast. snacks throughout the day, and snacks and alcoholic beverages from 7-8pm, and was subject to change so that we could do our other travel. This was a great value merely considering the price of breakfast pp and/or drinks added to the standard king room considerably exceeded our rate. The hotel shows little of its 20 year age with a fantastic Rufino Tamayo mural taking up a 80 x 200 foot wall of a first floor lounge. The room is spacious, well appointed, with a comfortable king bed and turn down service. Our floor was quiet though I would suggest that you book away from the 5300 wing that carries loud music from the gourmet china restaurant on the first floor. Check in for the club rooms is on the 5th floor which attends to your administrative needs-assistance is provided thru the concierge on the first floor which helped us with balletfolklorico tickets at a small additional $3 fee. Tourist taxis are available outside the hotel if desired at an average $18 ride to the centro historico or zocalo and $23 to the airport. Hotel service was very good as was dinner at the Bice restaurant and lunch at La Huerta on the ground levels of the hotel. If you came to df to see great art, make sure you visit the supreme court, the secretary of education buildings, and the Palace Bellas Artes to see the Rivera, Siquieros, and Orozco murals and the Tamayo museum in the nearby park for his modern art, the anthropology museum for crafts nd mexicoâ€™s cultures, and frida kahlo's house and museum in coyoacan best reached by taxi from the coyoacan or vivero metro stops--otherwise a long walk on relatively unpopulated streets. The pyramids are easily reached via the metro to terminal norte and the pyramids bus from there for a 1 hour ride. In centro historico, manage to have late lunch or dinner at Cafe Tacuba on Tacuba Street about 100 feet from the Allende metro stop and if at night, hop a cab at the nearby Sheraton to your hotel. During the day we found the metro safe but beware of rush hour where it can be wall to wall and difficult to enter or exit the cars particularly in the stops near the zocalo. Christmas period is usually polluytion free or not noticeable because most Mexicans go on vacation to the beaches or to places like san miguel. Overall, the hotel was excellent and the experience was fantastic.

Reviews.Title: “Camino Real Polanco, Mexico City”
Reviews.Author: LagunaMandy
Reviews.Content: This hotel I return to every time I visit Mexico City. The area, Polanco, is a great location, a wealthy area of Mexico City. As I am on business when I go to Mexico City, Polanco is my area of choice to stay. This hotel won architectural awards when built, it is low-rise, has a distinctly Mexican feel about it and is so unlike the mass -produced high rise hotels which, if you stay in, you could be anywhere in the world , they get that "sameness" about them. The Camino Real club floor includes a lovely breakfast looking out over the pool, as well as afternoon tea. I have stayed here many times and always have a great stay. The restaurants in the hotel are fantastic, sophisticated, world class . Great to entertain clients. No wonder the contestants in this year's Miss Universe were staying at this hotel! For a great Mexican restaurant in the area don't miss "Valentinas", fabulous Mole and mariachis included!

Reviews.Title: “Decent but NOT a Leading Hotel of the World”
Reviews.Author: nycaroundtheworld
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying that for $150 per night I should not be complaining; however, I absolutely cannot believe that this hotel is part of "The Leading Hotels of the World" group which is why I am writing this negative review as one expects certain standards from a LHW hotel. I got a regular room with a balcony. The balcony was great; however, it overlooked a decorative pool that looked like it was abandoned for months full of leaves okay not big deal but not something you would expect from a LHW. What was really disgusting was the bright green carpeting in our room that looked 20 years old and not vacuumed around the edges. It was so gross I would not walk barefoot. The bedding was gross. The bathroom was marble and large, it was nice but I did not feel it was clean. Minus the bathroom and balcony the room was something you would expect to find in a run down hotel I thought that I got a bad room because I paid only $150 but then I got to my friends room who got a suite and I was horrified. Aside from the bedding which was much nicer than in my room, the suite was even worse than the regular room I had. The carpet was bright purple, crumbs in the corner. Everything was completely outdated and it did not even have a balcony. The first word that comes to mind to describe this room would be skanky. The service by the pool was terrible. The staff was friendly and meant well, but they were very slow and kept on messing up our orders both times we were there. I almost lost my appetite when I opened the menu to find a squashed bug ... nice. What was great about this hotel is that they had many excellent restarants inside the hotel including Le Cirque, Bice, and the China Grill which had a good scene and very cool outdoor bar/lounge called Moon Bar. This was the best part of the hotel and perhaps the only reason I would stay again. The location was not great as I felt trapped in the hotel, but taxi's are cheap. You must have the hotel call a radio taxi which is a third of the cost of a hotel taxi. The W hotel is much better and in a much better location in Polenco. The best restarant I've been to in Mexico City is Ivorie which is about a 5-10 miniute taxi from the hotel. The food is excellent, the decor is beautiful, the crowd is classy, and there is a great bar on the 3rd floor.

Reviews.Title: “Watch the hotel exchange rate”
Reviews.Author: rco56
Reviews.Content: I hate the feeling of being ripped off, and it was inescapable here.
