Impressed by what I had heard about staying in Polanco, and the famous Camino Real in particular, I booked the Executive Floor for two weekend nights on the hotel website, for a price in US dollars that included all taxes and fees. Use of the club lounge was included, but the food at breakfast was skimpy, the waiter surly on both mornings and the ambiance a bit down at the heels. My room was spacious, but again in need of a facelift. But the real surprise was at checkout, when the hotel's Mexico-peso 'equivalent' of my confirmed US-dollar rate turned out to be about ten per cent higher than the official exchange rate. When I asked about this, the smiling Executive Club receptionist told me that the hotel uses a double exchange rate, one when you book (lower) and one when you pay (higher). She said that "all the hotels in Polanco do this". Whatever. I won't stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Better options for this hotel”
Reviews.Author: Marybel13
Reviews.Content: I stayed 6 nights at this hotel that was booked for me on a recent business trip to Mexico City. My feelings are mixed. I had a good stay and enjoyed the daily use of the gym and pool in the morning. However, breakfast is not included (225pesos pp), nor is wifi or internet connection throughout the hotel. You can get access per 24 hours (160 pesos) or bit less if booked throughout your stay. BTW wifi was extremely slow. So you may want to consider going to any of many available places like Starbucks/VIPS for well priced breakfast AND free wifi... As a frequent traveler I find it irritating when its clear that they try to earn some bucks on the most basic things. Furthermore, the lighting in the room was terrible. The hotel itself is very well known and there exist several other Camino Reals in Mexico. Having stayed only at this one I would advise staying at some of the other 5-star hotels in Polanco. Also since the location of Mariott /W /Nikko is closer to wider choice of restaurants and bars. There are several restaurants and bars available in the Camino Real itself and did try some. Coffeeshop was good, there is a cool bar on water (although smokey) but at the time they did not even have a menu so you have no idea what your drinks are costing until you get the bill. I also tried one of the restaurant (China Grill) -admittingly good food and very creative but expect at least 1000pesos pp. You can eat as good and better for less in some of the better restaurants in Polanco, Condesa and Roma. Tipping is expected by everyone and everywhere. All in all interesting to have stayed there once but would not book it myself again if up to me.

Reviews.Title: “Hated it; moved after 2 nights”
Reviews.Author: AtlantaTravelingirl
Reviews.Content: Hated the hotel. The halls were dark and smelled of the obnoxious cleaning solution. The rooms had poor lighting and even worse "desk space" -- definitely not set up for a business traveler. Not enough light in the bathroom to put on makeup! While there was not enough room light during waking hours; there was way too much at night while trying to sleep. The flourescent light over the room door bled into the room and met up with the neon sign light coming through the window curtains; had to sleep with my airline eye mask. This coupled with the rock-hard bed with sag areas along with the rock hard cheap foam pillows made for the worst night of sleep ever in my years of business (and personal) travel. While the hotel was close to the office, the convenience could not overcome the hotel's problems. The food was "ok". The gardens were beautiful. My 3 traveling companions hated the hotel as much as I did -- we all moved to the Intercontinental after 2 miserable nights here.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel”
Reviews.Author: WorldTravellerr
Reviews.Content: The hotel is a work of art. Beautiful, spacious, airy, timeless architecture. The rooms are very clean, good size and had wonderful large marble bathrooms. The bed was more comfortable than my own. Definitley the most comfortable I've slept on in all my travels to Mexico. The hotel staff was courteous, helpful and spoke excellent English. I got a decent internet rate of $140USD per night. The restaurants located in the hotel were upscale and pricey (think New York City). We had beers in the wonderful bar off the lobby, but ate all of our meals at the neighborhood restaurants. The Chapultepec neighborhood where the hotel is located is safe and provides many options for eating, drinking & entertainment. We had breakfast each day at a local diner called Los Bisquets. The food was excellent and moderately priced, $20USD for two people. We had dinner at a small food court called Cactus Bar which was immaculately clean, inexpensive and had the best tacos I've ever eaten (thanks Don Guerro!). The cost was around $15USD for tacos and beers for two people. We also ate at a very small, romantic Italian restaurant called L'arlecchino. The wood fired pizzas & pasta were excellent. The ambience was perfect (until they turned on the TV!). Service in each of these establishments was excellent. There were also several bars in the area, including an Irish pub, all which were very lively. During the day, we walked a few blocks to Chapultepec Park which is an oasis of green in the city. There is a castle which sits high on a hill overlooking the city which you can walk through. Many families come to the park on Sunday to socialize and enjoy the day. I highly recommend exploring the neighborhood and I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Great choice to stay at Mexico DF/City”
Reviews.Author: Davico
Reviews.Content: I was recommended to stay at Camino Real by a friend, who has been staying there for years. The hotel is located in a very safe area and the property is very nice, with a lot of restaurants (they even have one that is open 24 hours) and the rooms are huge. Anyway, that is what you expect from a 5 star hotel, though on the other hand they dont have many things to do inside the hotel apart from the swimming pool and a gym. The internet wireless conection was terrible (and i was on a business trip!), so I had to use a network cable. Everybody is very polite at the hotel (well, everywhere in Mexico people are very polite) and they are always willing to help. I give Camino Real 4/5 because although it is a great hotel and the price is really good ($150) I think they should update the facilities to be a real 5 star hotel. The architecture is great but a few things such as the internet conection can ruin your view about this hotel. Anyway, maybe it was just my laptop! I encourage travellers to consider this hotel as a serious option because anyway, if you go to Mexico City to visit the place, what you need is a comfortable place to spend the night... and Camino Real is the best option with such a low price.

Reviews.Title: “Marvelous Hotel”
Reviews.Author: cutlasciera
Reviews.Content: This is the first hotel that I have had no complaints about since they tore down the Millenium Hilton in NYC. The rooms were wonderful, the maids were excellent, the bathrooms were spacious, the building has its own water filtration plant, so you can not only drink the water, but you can favorably compare it to the tap water anywhere in America, the building itself was a work of art, and the building was filled with art. We were there for Santa Semana (slow time for business) so the hotel was filled with tourists who all were delighted by the marvelously low cost of their stay. I disagree with the comment about the concierges. They (especially Jorge Ortiz) were quite helpful: along with finding out which restaurants were open and helping us get they good seats for the Ballet Folklorico, they also stepped me through a scenario that involved getting a group of four non-Spanish speaking people back to the hotel after watching Luche Libre in a slightly rough neighborhood at eleven at night (that was the highlight of the trip, and I wouldn't have dared do it without their explicit instructions on how to have a safe walk to safe neighborhood with safe cabs. The guides offered by the hotel are a bit pricy: To round out a perfect Mexico vacation, I can only suggest that you stop by the lobby of the Majestic, and hire Emilio, Emilio is an eighty year old man who knows everybody in Mexico City and everything about Mexico City, and will show you things that even people who grew up in the DF have never noticed or seen.

Reviews.Title: “AS GOOD AS EXPECTED, Camino Real is a exceptional chain.”
Reviews.Author: mrrmdny
Reviews.Content: I booked a trip to conduct some business around X-mas 2006. I found a good deal on line and stayed here. I hadn't stayed here before though I have lived in this city before and visited it on several occasions. The rooms are large, clean and comfortable. The marble in the bathroom is attractive and the services available in the hotel are great. You do have to be careful with the "little things" like phone calls as you will pay a "fortune" for a call to a cell phone in mexico. If you use the internet you receive all your local calls free and you pay ten dlls a day for the wireless internet , all the local calls you make (except cell phone) are free. The room service was great, the Bice (Italian resturant) was very good too. One comment I read was that the taxi from the hotel was expensive. This is because the hotel employes a system that uses licenced tour guides that know the city and all of the attractions, history etc. This is expensive but well worth it for ease of use and for neophytes to feeel safe in the city..All in all I would tell anyone to stay here and would stay here again, it is a comfortable hotel with the longest walks to your room I've had in quite a while!

Reviews.Title: “Great experience”
Reviews.Author: VirginiaOlderCouple
Reviews.Content: Staying at the Camino Real was a wonderful experience. We had a garden view room which was very nicely furnished and equipped. It was quiet and had a very pleasant view of the garden and pool area. The staff could not have been more helpful and solicitous, even taking us on a personal guided tour of the public areas. The hotel itself was very impressive - modern, extremely well decorated, and with 5 first class restaurants all inside. Breakfast was also great. We were hesitant to book given some of the reports from earlier last year, but we found no evidence of construction or sloppy service - we unreservedly recommend staying here. We'd do it again if we go back to Mexico City. The hotel is in a nice and safe area, touring is easy. Incidentally, one day is not enough to see the City. The bill is hard to understand (multiple entries for each meal) and check out is slow, so leave time for that.

Reviews.Title: “With three kids, loved everything”
Reviews.Author: canbagna
Reviews.Content: I spent five nights at the hotel with my wife and three kids during our Christmas holidays. Everything was more than perfect. Service was great, as well as food (though a little bit expensive compared to Mexican standards). There is a very good choice of restaurants to dine at, going from classical mexican, to italian, french and chinese, as well as a coffe. The hot pool in the central patio was fantastic for kids and parents as well. Pros: mostly everyting Cons: luxury taxis at the hotel are a little expensive, say 140 MXP for a 15 minutes drive versus a 30-40 MXP on an ordinary taxis.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: WKCollection
Reviews.Content: I have just returned from the Camino Real. I found the hotel to be excellent in all areas ... and the staff extremely friendly and quick to tend to any needs that arose during my stay. The room was huge ... the patio was fantastic and comfortable ... and the red marbled bathroom was much more than expected .... a single bed could have fit into the shower with room to spare. The food at the hotel was very good .... and the service was excellent ..... The price of food at the hotel was extremely reasonable ..... remember that if it says $140 it means in pesos even on the English menu. The most important thing to me was that I was not just comfortable but felt very safe staying at the Camino Real. I felt safe walking in the area to the museums and taking a driver and car from the hotel to see other sites in the city which was arranged with superb service by the concierge. If you are like me ... and have never been to Mexico City before .... I would highly suggest you consider this wonderful hotel.

Reviews.Title: “A Great Choice”
Reviews.Author: casaros
Reviews.Content: We had a great stay at the Camino Real earlier this month. We were there 4 nights and stayed on the Club level. Each room cost us $170 dollars (a weekend rate, I think). There was plenty of vacancy, so you might try the internet for a better rate or negotiate to get one. We would have done so had we known how (relatively) empty the hotel was (probably not more than 50-60% full). We were glad to have stayed on the Club level. The hotel, as noted by others below, is beautiful and very comfortable. The architecture is great, the public areas clean and elegant, the restaurants excellent (we ate at the Italian one the first night to avoid having to go out and the food was excellent but perhaps a bit pricey), the rooms spacious and nicely designed. Room service was prompt and good, and housekeeping was very responsive. With three kids, safety was important, and we felt very safe in the hotel and allowed our kids to roam around as necessary. A nice and perfectly adequate breakfast was served each morning on the Club level with meats, cheeses, cereals, breads, fruit, yogurt, etc. It was a nice way to start the day. We were a family of 5 and needed two rooms. As it turned out, while there are connecting rooms on the Club level and elsewhere, we should have spoken directly to the Club level to ensure that our rooms were connecting. Our kids are old enough so that it was not a problem, but it was an annoyance that the left hand did not know what the right was doing (or capable of doing). One negative regarding the hotel is perhaps the location during this protest season. We pretty much felt as if we needed to take a cab or car everywhere. In that sense, it is not as nicely situated as Polanco (some say the hotel is in Polanco, but if it is it is at an extreme border). Regardless, that negative was not great and we would certainly stay at this hotel again and not hessitate to recommend it to others. Finally, we too tried El Fogoncito (behind the hotel). We enjoyed the tacos, quesadillas and beer. Good value, clean, and fun. Thanks to those that suggested that we try it. Our trip report can be found at: http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g150800-i164-k750296-Trip_Report_August_4_7-Mexico_City_Central_Mexico_and_Gulf_Coast.html

Reviews.Title: “Interesting...”
Reviews.Author: BarrieB
Reviews.Content: large rooms - club upgrade - good food - efficient - great architecture - bright colours - huge corridors - interesting stay

Reviews.Title: “Great deal at Camino Real”
Reviews.Author: goldmanm
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Camino Real for one night in April 2006 - we would not normally have selected this upscale a hotel, but we got a great deal through Expedia - $85/night. We found the rooms to be very quiet and the beds very comfortable - two things that you don't often find in hotels in Mexico. We had a great buffet lunch at the restaurant at the pool - very pricey, however - it ended up costing more then our rooms. Also, note that we choose the Camino Real because of its proximity to Chapultapec Park and the Anthropology Museum. It was very close, however, at the time we were there, a good portion of Chapultapec Park was closed off for "renovation" - this made our walk to the Anthropology Museum much longer than anticipated. However, still reasonably convenient. Lastly, I must pass on a tip provided by GoMexico - if you go out the back entrance of the hotel onto Calle Liebnitz, there are several small restaurants that specialize in tacos al pasteur and we had a great meal at one of them. Nothing fancy, but great food.

Reviews.Title: “Just Excellent option in Mexico City”
Reviews.Author: mtymd
Reviews.Content: Excellent facility!!! I stayed 3 nights in December and we had a great experience, the Hotel is in perfect conditions, excellent service and first class restaurants. The Hotel was built in 1968 due to the Olimpic Games in Mexico City by the worldwide famous mexican architect Ricardo Legorreta.

HotelInfo.Name: Camino Real Mexico City
HotelInfo.Address: Mariano Escobedo 700 | Colonia Anzúres, Mexico City 11590, Mexico
